message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms, including shortness of breath and cough, suggest asthma. Spirometry indicates an obstructive pattern, meaning that air is trapped in the lungs. The most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy would be a combination inhaler with both a corticosteroid (such as budesonide) and a long-acting bronchodilator (such as formoterol). This combination can help reduce inflammation in the airways and relax the muscles surrounding them. Fluticasone alone (option B) may not be enough to address the underlying inflammation. Oral montelukast (option C) is a leukotriene receptor antagonist and may not be as effective as the combination inhaler. Option D suggests using two different medications, but a combination inhaler would be a simpler and more effective option initially.

The most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy for asthma is an inhaler containing a combination of a corticosteroid and a long-acting beta agonist, such as budesonide and formoterol. Fluticasone inhaler is another corticosteroid inhaler and can be used as an alternative. Montelukast sodium is a leukotriene receptor antagonist and can be used as an alternative for patients who cannot tolerate or do not respond to inhaled corticosteroids. Mometasone inhaler and oral zafirlukast are not typically used as initial pharmacotherapy for asthma.
